subject: fru-device: add FRUReader EEPROM cache
commitMessage:
fru-device: add FRUReader EEPROM cache

This doesn't provide a huge benefit currently, but is a preparatory step
for adding support for a wider variety of FRU format parsers.  If
parsers for multiple formats are interested in reading the same areas of
an EEPROM, the caching provided by this abstraction avoids the redundant
bus traffic of all of them re-reading the same bytes over and over.

Tested: on an ASRock Rack romed8hm3, fru-device successfully recognizes
and parses the baseboard FRU EEPROM as it did prior to this patch.

Signed-off-by: Zev Weiss <zev@bewilderbeest.net>
Change-Id: I0d774508bc29dbda346309fe7fe42dbdf97bee43

Patch Set 23: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 309c0b13646b747bd35e63dd53ad38d6f129ff53
Please add a comment indicating what the return value means.
Ack

Can you please add a note on what the return value of read / ReadBlockFunc indicated? I.e. does either of which "guarantee" to read the requested len, or do they just read "as much as possible" and it might require subsequent calls to read?
Ack

Actually, after looking into this a bit further, nailing down the exact semantics of the return value here looks trickier than I'd thought, mostly w.r.t. EOF.

In the readFromEeprom() case we're just reading from a (sysfs) file, so mirroring read(2) semantics is easy.

For readBlockData() though, we're doing direct, manual i2c transfers, which means we're beholden to whatever the device's behavior is -- on one example FRU EEPROM I tested with, reading past the end of it doesn't NACK the transaction or anything, it just returns made-up (0xff) bytes, so it doesn't look like there'd be any reliable way of determining when to indicate EOF to the caller (i.e. return non-negative but less than 'len').

That said, in practice it may not ultimately be a big problem, since none of the FRU format parsers I'm aware of at the moment actually need to be able to detect EOF, they just try to read as many bytes as they're looking for, and if those bytes are bogus presumably (hopefully) the parse will just fail.  So I guess the semantics will just be a bit weaker in that area than I'd been thinking at first.
Are the semantics of read different here? Please add a comment.

No, the intent is that all implementations of the FRUReader abstract base class will provide the same semantics for the `::read()` operation as described in the comment in the base class, so I didn't think it was necessary to duplicate it in the derived classes.

I'm not sure about the usual style here, but I would have though that we'd indicate that this is a constant somehow? When I just read the code that's using it, I was wondering whether this is a variable.
That was my inclination too, but when I initially wrote it as CACHE_BLOCK_SIZE the CI style checks complained, so I changed it to match e.g. fruBlockSize, which I guess is the preferred style.
This is the first time you mentioned "EEPROM" here. Should this be something like "max offset available from ReadBlockFunc"?
Yeah, I suppose that's perhaps a bit overly specific, I think I'll rename it to EOF as a slightly more generic alternative and avoid talking about EEPROMs entirely.
This variable name makes me think this was true / false (!= 0, == 0), which is not the case. Maybe use a different name? "maybeIs16Bit"?

`maybeIs16Bit` to me makes it sound like a true value would indicate that the device might be 16-bit but we don't really know, which seems more confusing to me.  Given that the following line handles the `< 0` error case fairly unambiguously I thought it was reasonably clear (certainly more so than the completely non-descriptive name `flag`).  It's maybe getting a little further afield from the intent of this patch, but perhaps I'll change it to be a `std::optional<bool>`.
Nice, thank you!

Shouldn't we also set the eepromSize here? This would cover the case where the size of the EEPROM is divisible by the cacheBlockSize - which I think it's pretty likely. Otherwise we'll continue trying to read something that's not there, not taking advantage of eepromSize.

The only cases where line 80 above won't set eepromSize are if the read fails entirely (ret < 0) or if we get all the bytes we asked for (ret == cacheBlockSize, in which case we don't know that it's EOF), so I think the preceding logic already takes care of that.
LGTM, thank you!
As a design pattern, I very much prefer composition over inheritance, especially in cases where we're adding methods and overriding everything from the inherited class.
Okay, I'll look into that.
Done
Considering that we're not going to iterate this, and don't care about order, would std::unordered_map be a better choice here?
Ack
Just FYI, we've discussed before that this code doesn't actually work, and can likely be removed.  Not an issue with your patch, just so you're aware.

Is there a reason that CachingFRUReader can't just call this directly?  Having a lambda being injected doesn't seem used anywhere, and adds complexity for something that doesn't seem like it needs to be extensible.

It's used to differentiate between the cases that call `readFromEeprom()` (reading from a kernel-provided sysfs file) and the ones that call `readBlockData()` to read via manual i2c-dev ioctls.  It's also a convenient way for the unit tests to plug in a read callback that just returns fixed test data without mucking around with doing actual I/O.
This should be an rvalue (assuming it's still needed at all).

Sorry, but I'm afraid this may be running up against the limits of my C++ knowledge -- could you provide a link to some sort of reading material with a bit more explanation?  (Or just a bit more detail here.)  Web searches for "C++ rvalue" aren't turning up anything obviously relevant...

I think Ed is suggesting to do this:

```
std::vector<uint8_t> device = readFRUContents(FRUReader(readFunc), errorMessage);
```

Hmm, Ed's initial comment seemed to be directed at the `readFunc` constructor argument specifically, rather than the `reader` object constructed from it, so I'm not sure...also, would that change have any effect other than perhaps running the CachingFRUReader destructor a bit earlier?  (At the end of the statement instead of the end of the enclosing scope, I think...)  If that's the only functional difference, I guess I don't really see the benefit.

Ed, can you clarify?

Sorry for not replying to this quickly.  What i meant was that you should be std::moveing readFunc, like

FruReader reader(std::move(readFunc)).

With that said, that's a good pattern to have, but in this case on my part was largely bikeshedding, given that the struct for the lambda only includes file, which is an int, and should copy trivially.

Up to you if you want to do it, I suspect the optimizer will generate the same machine code in either case.

Okay, thanks for clarifying -- in this case the FRUReader constructor already has a `std::move()` call in it though, so is there a benefit to also having a move at the call site?  (I'm fairly hazy on these things, but I would have assumed that one was enough.)
There is still a benefit, because in this scope that we're looking at, readFunc would be moved instead of copied.
Done
Why does the cursor variable need to exist at all?  start doesn't look modified or read after this point, so it' looks like just another name for start?  Same thing with len/remaining.
Please declare each variable on its own line, as is done elsewhere.

`cursor` is the point from which it's currently reading, and while it starts out as `start`, it does get updated at the end of the loop after we've successfully copied data to `outbuf` (`cursor += toCopy`).  `remaining` is likewise decremented at the same point.

It's probably possible to express the same logic with fewer book-keeping variables (and this function did turn out to be a good bit more intricate than I was expecting/hoping it would be), but with the various edge-cases that arose as I was writing it this was the clearest way I could come up with to do it -- there's an earlier incarnation of this logic in patchset 8, but I thought this was an improvement overall.
Ack
init your variables.  There's lots that you've failed to init, please fix all of them.
Doesn't the logic in the else case produce zero as well without needing to special case this?

I think I had it that way at first, and that holds if `blkOffset == populated`, but if `blkOffset > populated`, then the subtraction in the `min()` call underflows to a large positive value and you end up with `remaining` instead of zero.  `blkOffset > populated` probably shouldn't arise in any common cases, but could with an oddly-sized eeprom and an attempt to read a bit past the end of it.
Isn't this logic duplicated with the above flow?  eof gets set properly on the cache object on line 79, so in theory this logic could be used in both cases to delete a majority of the other logic?
Perhaps so, I'll take a look at condensing the two branches together a bit.
Done

I know you didn't write this, but since we're all looking at it more closely now: Shouldn't this be

ssize_t readFromEeprom(int fd, off_t offset, size_t len, uint8_t *buf)?

I'm worried about casting ssize_t to int64_t on systems where ssize_t really is int32_t, since that causes unnecessary overhead. I'd say that these types should then trickle down into all the other methods using them. The advantage of size_t / ssize_t and off_t is that they're descriptive, whereas int32_t / int64_t could be anything.

WDYT?
Yeah, I think that would make sense -- perhaps I'll shim in a preparatory patch doing some initial type conversions and then rebase this series on top of that.
Now addressed in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/52249
See comment on use of off_t vs size_t in the other review.
This signature doesn't match what FRUReader expects ... Does this compile?

Hmm, that's a good point -- it definitely seems to compile for me (and CI seems to agree), though I'd agree that it's surprising that it isn't an error (but I've never been terribly clear on what goes on with implicit type conversions in C++ anyway, sigh...).  I'll change this to be more self-consistent.
Done
As above.
Shouldn't these two also be size_t for consistency?
Ack -- yeah, that sounds appropriate; I'll change it to that.
Done
Does this class definition and implementation deserve its own file?
No particular opinion here, happy to split it out if you think that'd be more appropriate.
Done

std::hash<uint32_t> is the identity function, which means this api is going to produce REALLY bad hash values.

I realize this is a super subtle data structure thing, but I suspect this is a case where we should be using std::map, because there is *some* ordering to our cache.
Ah, good to know, hadn't been aware of that -- I'll make it a `std::map` instead.
Done

Generally for these apis we just do if (!is16Bit)


Super nitpicky, fix if you want.

I'd probably be inclined to do it that way for just about anything else, but in the specific case where the optional is a bool the "absent" vs "present but false" distinction seems a little potentially confusing to me...

can we do something like is16BitBool{*is16Bit} here;  Technically from the lambda context you should be doing a safety check, but if you do the deference in the calling scope, static analyzers won't care.

I'm not sure I quite follow what this is about, sorry...do you mean just to arrange things so that the lambda receives a plain bool instead of a `std::optional<bool>`?  I can certainly just add another local variable to the caller if so.
Made that change in the current revision, lemme know if I misunderstood what you meant.
Realized that with the rebase after https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/52578 there was one more return value that needed an update, now fixed.
